OED to host follow-up Unemployment Insurance Rules Advisory Committee (RAC) virtual meeting Oct. 13 (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="Graphical user interface

AI-generated content may be incorrect." src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:75px; width:287px" /></p>

<p>Oct. 10, 2025</p>

<p>Media Contact: <a href="mailto:seth.c.gordon@employ.oregon.gov">seth.c.gordon@employ.oregon.gov</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:18px">MEDIA ADVISORY</span></p>

<p style="text-align: center;">Oregon Employment Department to host follow-up Unemployment Insurance Rules Advisory Committee (RAC) virtual meeting Oct. 13</p>

<p><br />
The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is proposing changes to three Oregon Administrative Rules related to Unemployment Insurance (UI). OED will host a second virtual Rules Advisory Committee (RAC) meeting via Zoom from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Monday, Oct. 13, to gather input and recommendations on the proposed rule changes.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>You are invited to attend the virtual meeting and can RSVP using the following link: <a href="https://www.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_qytWtI-OQHicz_lXcRxJTA"><strong>UI Rules Advisory Committee Oct. 13 video conference</strong></a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>OED has drafted changes to the following rules:</p>

<ul>
     <li>471-010-0105 (4) – Customer Information and Disclosure: General Disclosures</li>
     <li>471-030-0050 (3) – Benefit Payments</li>
     <li>471-030-0036 – Eligibility factors</li>
</ul>

<p>The initial meeting was held virtually on Oct. 2, but the committee did not finish discussing proposed changes to 471-030-0036, which defines the weekly eligibility requirements for being able to work, available for work, and actively seeking work.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The meeting on Oct. 13 will focus primarily on proposed changes to section (5), subsection (d), which were not discussed at the initial meeting. These proposed changes are intended to clarify how OED will implement Senate Bill 916 (2025) and administer limited UI benefits to striking workers beginning in 2026.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>More information, including the draft rule language, video of the first meeting, and upcoming meeting agenda are available on the <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/agency/pages/administrative-rules.aspx" target="_blank"><strong>OED administrative rules page</strong></a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Next steps:</strong></p>

<ul>
     <li>File proposed rules with Secretary of State: Oct. 24 (proposed)</li>
     <li>Public Comment Period: Nov. 4-Dec. 5</li>
     <li>Public Hearing (virtual): Nov. 19</li>
     <li>File final rules with Secretary of State: Dec. 26 (proposed)</li>
     <li>Rules become effective: January 4, 2026.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: center;">###</p>

<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken-language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

Oregon Employment Department adjusts monthly media plans amid federal shutdown (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="Graphical user interface

AI-generated content may be incorrect." src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:75px; width:287px" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Oct. 13, 2025</strong></p>

<p><strong>Media Contact:</strong> <a href="mailto:Communications@employ.oregon.gov">Communications@employ.oregon.gov</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:24px">MEDIA ADVISORY</span></p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><em>Oregon Employment Department adjusts </em></strong><strong><em>monthly media plans amid federal shutdown</em></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Salem, Ore.</strong> – Due to the ongoing federal shutdown, the Oregon Employment Department (OED) is unable to share some labor market data and is adjusting its monthly economic reporting and media activities for the week of Oct. 13-17.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although the unemployment rate and nonfarm payroll data for Oregon in September is not available during the shutdown, OED will share what data is available in its regularly scheduled statewide press release on Wednesday, Oct. 15.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The department will not host a media briefing this week, but will release a media statement on Thursday, Oct. 16 with agency updates, including the latest Unemployment Insurance claims data and an upgrade to Frances Online functionality for employers.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This situation continues to change quickly, and OED will continue to adapt in order to provide the public, our partners, and the media with accurate economic and labor market information.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>###</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken-language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

Seasonal trends driving recent increase in initial Unemployment Insurance claims (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="Graphical user interface

AI-generated content may be incorrect." src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:75px; width:287px" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:</strong></p>

<p>Oct. 16, 2025</p>

<p>Media Contact: <a href="mailto:Communications@employ.oregon.gov">Communications@employ.oregon.gov</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:20px">MEDIA STATEMENT</span></p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><em>Seasonal trends driving recent increase in initial Unemployment Insurance claims </em></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Salem, Ore.</strong> – Driven primarily by annual seasonal trends, initial Unemployment Insurance (UI) claims in Oregon have risen over the past two weeks. This increase was expected and falls within OED projections entering the agency’s busiest period of the year from October through February.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>“As expected, we’re not seeing a major impact on our workload from the ongoing federal shutdown, but we recognize the uncertainty and financial strain this has caused for many Oregonians,” UI Director Lindsi Leahy said. “We remain ready to support Oregonians.”</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>OED has detailed guidance for federal employees at <a href="https://unemployment.oregon.gov/federal-shutdown">OED’s Federal Shutdown page</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although federal claims data is still preliminary, new applications from federal employees have increased in recent weeks. Because federal employees represent a small share of Oregon’s workforce (about 1.5%), and the shutdown only accounts for some of those claims, the shutdown has likely played a limited role in the overall increase.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As shown in the table below, initial claims were, on average, 25 percent higher for the past two weeks compared to the final full week of September. Weekly claims have also risen during that period, but the increases have been smaller.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;">Initial and Weekly UI Claims – Sept. 21 – Oct. 11</p>

<table align="center" border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
     <tbody>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:125px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Week</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:128px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Initial Claims</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:110px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Percent Change</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:130px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Weekly Claims</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:131px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Percent Change</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:125px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Sept. 21-27</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:128px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">2,550</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:110px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">-</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:130px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">33,960</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:131px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">-</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:125px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Sept. 28-Oct. 4</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:128px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">3,294</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:110px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">+29%</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:130px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">35,107</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:131px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">+3.3%</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:125px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">Oct. 5-11</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:128px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">3,129</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:110px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">-5%</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:130px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">35,320</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:131px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">+0.6%</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:125px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">2-week avg.</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:128px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">3,207</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:110px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">+25%</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:130px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">35,213</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:131px">
               <p style="text-align: center;">+3.7%</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
     </tbody>
</table>

<div style="clear:both;">&nbsp;</div>

<p><strong>About Federal Claims</strong></p>

<p>Preliminary data indicates the number of federal employees applying for benefits has also increased over the past two weeks. OED can only estimate those figures because claims that include wages from federal employers take weeks for OED to process and confirm. That delay stems from the fact that, unlike most other employers in Oregon, the federal government does not submit quarterly wage data to OED, and it often takes weeks for OED to receive that information after a federal employee files a claim.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Some initial claims with federal wages filed over the past two weeks may result from regular seasonal federal layoffs or deferred buyout agreements that expired at the end of the federal fiscal year on Sept. 30, so OED cannot determine exactly how many are tied to the federal shutdown.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>OED does track Unemployment Compensation for Federal Employees (UCFE) claims as part of reporting to the U.S. Department of Labor, but that data takes weeks to finalize. This metric does not represent all claims from federal workers because UCFE only includes cases where all wages were from the federal government.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As of Oct. 15, OED has confirmed 118 UCFE claims for the week of Sept. 28-Oct. 4, or roughly 3.6 percent of all initial claims that week. Last week, 178 of the 3,129 initial claims (or 5.7% percent) were confirmed as UCFE. These figures will continue to change as additional information becomes available and should not be interpreted as the total number of furloughed federal employees in Oregon who have applied for benefits.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>###</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken-language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

Oregon Employment Department Announces Intent to Award Contract for Workforce Modernization Project (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="Picture 3, Picture" src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:61px; width:237px" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</strong><br />
Oct. 31, 2025</p>

<p>Media Contact: <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov"><strong>communications@employ.oregon.gov</strong></a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:18px"><strong><em>Oregon Employment Department Announces Intent to Award Contract for Workforce Modernization Project</em></strong></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Salem, Ore.&nbsp;— The Oregon Employment Department (OED), in partnership with the Department of Administrative Services State Procurement Services (DAS-SPS), is excited to announce its Notice of Intent to Award to Career Team Enterprises, a major milestone in the Workforce Modernization Project. Career Team Enterprises is the top-ranking candidate that will develop the modernized technical solution to support both state employment services and federal workforce programs in Oregon.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Workforce Modernization Project is a multi-year, system-wide initiative that involves multiple agencies and community partners. &nbsp;The project goes beyond technology. OED’s Modernization Division has spent significant time gathering input from customers, staff, and partners to understand what is working and what is not. This feedback is shaping both the technical solution and also the business processes that it supports. The goal is to create a modern, user-friendly experience that meets the needs of all Oregonians and strengthens the entire workforce ecosystem.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This intent to award is an important step toward delivering better, faster, and more accessible services to Oregonians. The new system will focus on the customers – helping job seekers, employers, and workforce partners by making it easier to connect with the tools and support they need. It will also improve how OED staff work behind the scenes, enabling more efficient and responsive service delivery.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>“We are thrilled to reach this point in the project,” said Andrew R. Stolfi, Employment Department Director. “This progress reflects the dedication and hard work of our team, as well as the invaluable support from our workforce partners and local workforce boards. Together, we’re building a system that works better for everyone.”</p>

<p>While the final contract has not yet been signed, the Notice of Intent to Award (NITA) marks the end of the procurement evaluation phase and the beginning of contract negotiations.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Learn more about the Workforce Modernization Project at <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/Agency/Pages/Learn-About-Modernization.aspx">the OED website</a>.</p>

<div>
<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;">###</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>About the Oregon Employment Department </strong></p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) provides economic stability to Oregon communities by providing vital services to both businesses and workers. &nbsp;OED supports businesses with finding qualified job candidates, labor market information, tax incentives and support, and retaining talent through economic downturns. OED promotes employment through wage replacement benefits during unemployment and significant life events, job placement, training, and useful career information. Learn more at <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/Pages/default.aspx">employment.oregon.gov.</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>About Workforce Operations</strong></p>

<p>OED’s Workforce Operations division is a partner in WorkSource Oregon, a consortium of state agencies and local workforce boards, and it operates 37 WorkSource Oregon centers across the state. WorkSource Oregon offers a wide range of free services, including personalized career coaching, resume writing, interview practice, and job search strategies. For employers and businesses, WorkSource Oregon provides support for job postings and finding qualified candidates, hiring incentives, and access to labor-market data – all at no cost. Visit <a href="https://www.worksourceoregon.org/">worksourceoregon.org</a> for more information.</p>

<div>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.govc">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

headline: Yakima School District Board Named 2025 Board of Distinction
Oregon Legislators Recognized as Public Health Champions as 2025 Session Fails to Fund Critical Health Investments (Photo)
detail:
<h1 dir="ltr"><img alt="Text

Description automatically generated with low confidence" src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:146.99600472397418; margin-left:-18.486505270473764px; margin-top:0px; width:776.0917409938608" /><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:23pt">FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</span></h1>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Contact:</strong><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">Allison Mora, Public Health Program Manager</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">Coalition of Local Health Officials</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">971-480-0752</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">allison@oregonclho.org</span></p>

<h2 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:17pt">Oregon Legislators Recognized as Public Health Champions as 2025 Session Fails to Fund Critical Health Investments</span></h2>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">CLHO Releases Legislative Scorecard Highlighting Leadership While Calling on Governor, Legislative Leaders to Prioritize Public Health Funding</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>PORTLAND, OR – November 3rd, 2025</strong><span style="font-size:11pt"> – Despite advancing its most ambitious public health agenda to date, the Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO) announced today that no new investments in Oregon's public health system were made during the 2025 legislative session. The organization's Legislative Scorecard recognizes lawmakers who championed public health priorities while highlighting the urgent need for future funding to support the state's underfunded public health infrastructure.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"The 2025 legislative session was a difficult one," said Sarah Lochner, CLHO Executive Director. "Economic uncertainty drove down Oregon's revenue forecast, leaving the Legislature with tough choices to make. But year after year, public health gets pushed aside—and Oregon's communities pay the price."</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">CLHO advanced a comprehensive public health agenda this session, advocating for investments in Public Health Modernization, the public health workforce, addiction primary prevention, and maternal and child health, along with stronger policies for synthetic nicotine regulation and taxation. But many proposals stalled in the Joint Committee on Ways and Means and never came to a full chamber vote, leaving Oregon's public health system underfunded yet again.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">As a result, many legislators earned a 0% on this year's scorecard—not because they opposed public health, but because the Legislature failed to act on key bills that would have strengthened Oregon's health infrastructure.</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">Recognizing 2025 Public Health Champions</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Despite the challenging session, several legislators demonstrated exceptional leadership on public health priorities, earning recognition as Public Health Champions, Rising Stars, and members of the Public Health Honor Roll.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Champions</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Legislators who went above and beyond to advance public health this session, earning the highest tier of recognition on our scorecard. These champions also earned extra credit by repeatedly stepping up for public health.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Rob Nosse – 143%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Hai Pham – 143%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Travis Nelson – 129%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Deb Patterson – 117%</strong></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Rising Stars: </strong><span style="font-size:11pt">Senators who demonstrated strong support for public health and the CLHO agenda, earning 100% and the second tier of recognition on this year's scorecard.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Courtney Neron Misslin – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Floyd Prozanski – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. James Manning, Jr. – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Honor Roll</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Legislators who stepped up, many for the first time, to support CLHO's top priorities and demonstrated a clear commitment to protecting and strengthening Oregon's public health system, scoring 100%.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Tom Andersen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Willy Chotzen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Lisa Fragala</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Mark Gamba</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Shannon Isadore</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Lesly Munoz</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Hoa Nguyen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Sue Rieke Smith</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Jules Walters</span></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"We are grateful to the champions, rising stars, and others who stood up for public health during the 2025 session," Lochner said. "These legislators understand that a strong public health system isn't a luxury—it's the foundation of healthy communities and a thriving economy."</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">What Was at Stake</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The scorecard focused on five of CLHO’s top legislative priorities, which included:</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 3916 – Public Health Workforce Package</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Addressing critical staffing shortages in local health departments across Oregon</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 2954 – Addiction Primary Prevention</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Investing in primary prevention programs to stop substance use before it starts</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 2528 – Synthetic Nicotine Regulation</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Strengthening protections for youth against unregulated and emerging nicotine products</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Modernization Funding</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Building a stronger, more flexible statewide public health system</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Maternal and Child Health Investments</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Supporting healthy pregnancies and early childhood development</span></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Without these investments, Oregon's local health departments continue to operate with limited resources, understaffed teams, and reduced capacity to respond to emerging health threats.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">&nbsp;“Flat funding is actually a funding decrease,” Lochner emphasized. “Rising staff costs mean the funding we have buys less this year than it did last year—so even maintaining current service levels becomes impossible.”</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">Call to Action</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">CLHO is urging Governor Kotek and legislative leadership to prioritize public health in future agency budgets and legislative sessions.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"Oregon can't afford to keep underfunding prevention," Lochner said. "We've seen what happens when we don't invest in public health—communities suffer, health disparities grow, health insurance costs skyrocket, and we end up spending more on crisis response instead of prevention. It's time for that to change."</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The full scorecard, including detailed methodology, is available at </span><a href="http://oregonclho.org/advocacy" style="text-decoration-line: none;"><strong>oregonclho.org/advocacy</strong></a><span style="font-size:11pt">.</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">About CLHO</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO) is a statewide coalition representing Oregon's local health departments and health officials. CLHO advocates for policies and resources that strengthen Oregon's public health system, promote health equity, and support the health of communities served by local health departments across the state.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">For more information about CLHO's legislative priorities and the 2025 Legislative Scorecard, visit </span><a href="http://oregonclho.org/advocacy" style="text-decoration-line: none;"><strong>oregonclho.org/advocacy</strong></a><span style="font-size:11pt">.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>###</strong></p>

<div>&nbsp;</div>
org: Oregon Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO)
